articles.headline: President Obama Eulogizes Charleston Pastor as One Who Understood Grace
articles.snippet: The president invoked the concept of grace and began to sing “Amazing Grace.”
articles.abstract: The president invoked the concept of grace and began to sing “Amazing Grace.”
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — In one of his presidency’s most impassioned reflections on race, President Obama eulogized the Rev. Clementa C. Pinckney on Friday by calling on the nation to emulate the grace that he displayed in his work and that the people of South Carolina demonstrated after the massacre of nine worshipers at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church.
articles.byline: By Kevin Sack and Gardiner Harris

articles.headline: Greek Prime Minister Calls for Referendum on Bailout Terms
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras accused creditors of presenting Greece with unfair terms and called on citizens to decide how to respond.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras accused creditors of presenting Greece with unfair terms and called on citizens to decide how to respond.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — In an unexpected move, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras went on national television early Saturday to call for a referendum on July 5, so that Greek citizens can decide whether to accept or reject the terms of a bailout deal proposed by the country’s creditors.
articles.byline: By Jim Yardley and Niki Kitsantonis

articles.headline: Car Seats That Make Sure the Baby on Board Is Snug and Safe
articles.snippet: All seats need to meet federal safety standards but, aside from aesthetics, are the more expensive ones worth the extra cost in terms of extra security?
articles.abstract: All seats need to meet federal safety standards but, aside from aesthetics, are the more expensive ones worth the extra cost in terms of extra security?
articles.lead_paragraph: As soon as expectant parents go public with their big news, the baby gear bonanza begins: Cribs that transform into toddler beds, self-folding strollers that charge cellphones and the millions of smaller-ticket items, like the $15 Swedish-designed contraption that does a superior job of clearing out your baby’s nose. (It really does).

articles.headline: Crying Foul on Plans to Expand the S.E.C.’s In-House Court System
articles.snippet: The agency’s use of internal trials has raised questions about fairness because defendants may not have all the same rights they have in federal court.
articles.abstract: The agency’s use of internal trials has raised questions about fairness because defendants may not have all the same rights they have in federal court.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the top cop on Wall Street, the Securities and Exchange Commission usually enjoys broad support for its work fighting fraud in the nation’s financial markets. But a recent agency stance has generated such criticism that even some of the S.E.C.’s high-powered alumni are calling for a do-over.

articles.headline: Hard Politicking Behind Democrats’ ‘Yea’ Votes on Trade Bill
articles.snippet: The campaign to get Democratic support for the Pacific Rim trade pact began more than a year ago, and came down to four days of tight maneuvering by G.O.P. leaders and the White House.
articles.abstract: The campaign to get Democratic support for the Pacific Rim trade pact began more than a year ago, and came down to four days of tight maneuvering by G.O.P. leaders and the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the evening of June 15, President Obama joined a conference call with the two men who had done more than anyone in six years to disrupt, derail or defeat his agenda in Congress. Now they were asking for something that was in short supply: trust.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: ‘Drunk Wedding’ Faced Too High a Bar to the Big Screen
articles.snippet: Paramount Pictures’ microbudget comedy “Drunk Wedding” had a successful screening and the studio’s support, but it was still left at the altar.
articles.abstract: Paramount Pictures’ microbudget comedy “Drunk Wedding” had a successful screening and the studio’s support, but it was still left at the altar.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the spring of 2013, Paramount Pictures held a research screening at a multiplex here for a new comedy called “Drunk Wedding.” The studio’s vice chairman was so eager to learn the results that he attended in person.

articles.headline: Fireworks Prohibitions Ease in Many States
articles.snippet: For the first time in more than a century, shoppers in New York can buy some types of fireworks, as the state joins a nationwide movement on relaxing restrictions.
articles.abstract: For the first time in more than a century, shoppers in New York can buy some types of fireworks, as the state joins a nationwide movement on relaxing restrictions.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWBURGH, N.Y. — After stocking up on sparklers and flaming fountains, Don Eason couldn’t resist adding one more impulse buy to his incendiary items: a Fiery Frog, which promises to erupt in a column of crackling, multicolor sparks.

articles.headline: Historic Day for Gays, but Twinge of Loss for an Outsider Culture
articles.snippet: As the gay marriage movement peaks, so does a debate about whether gay identity is dimming, overtaken by its own success.
articles.abstract: As the gay marriage movement peaks, so does a debate about whether gay identity is dimming, overtaken by its own success.
articles.lead_paragraph: From Capitol Hill in Seattle to Dupont Circle in Washington, gay bars and nightclubs have turned into vitamin stores, frozen yogurt shops and memories. Some of those that remain are filled increasingly with straight patrons, while many former customers say their social lives now revolve around preschools and playgrounds.

articles.headline: ISIS and the Lonely Young American
articles.snippet: For months, Alex had been growing closer to a new group of friends online — the kindest she had ever had — who were teaching her what it meant to be a Muslim.
articles.abstract: For months, Alex had been growing closer to a new group of friends online — the kindest she had ever had — who were teaching her what it meant to be a Muslim.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alex, a 23-year-old Sunday school teacher and babysitter, was trembling with excitement the day she told her Twitter followers that she had converted to Islam.

articles.headline: Does a Pistol Belong in Your Stock Portfolio?
articles.snippet: After the Charleston shooting, individual investors still hold shares in gun companies, which have seen a rise in sales and stock prices following similar tragedies.
articles.abstract: After the Charleston shooting, individual investors still hold shares in gun companies, which have seen a rise in sales and stock prices following similar tragedies.
articles.lead_paragraph: A white man sat in a historic black church in Charleston, S.C., on June 17 and then proceeded to gun down nine people in a Bible study group. That mass murder has prompted national soul-searching on racism and renewed calls for stricter national gun control regulations.

articles.headline: Next Fight for Gay Rights: Bias in Jobs and Housing
articles.snippet: Exhilarated by the Supreme Court’s endorsement of same-sex marriage, gay rights advocates have turned their sights on what they see as the next big battle: antidiscrimination laws.
articles.abstract: Exhilarated by the Supreme Court’s endorsement of same-sex marriage, gay rights advocates have turned their sights on what they see as the next big battle: antidiscrimination laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: Exhilarated by the Supreme Court’s endorsement of same-sex marriage, gay rights leaders have turned their sights to what they see as the next big battle: obtaining federal, state and local legal protections in employment, housing, commerce and other arenas, just like those barring discrimination based on race, religion, sex and national origin.

articles.headline: Straddling Old and New, a South Where ‘a Flag Is Not Worth a Job’
articles.snippet: The massacre at a church in Charleston, S.C., this month casts the tensions between the Old South and the New into sharp relief.
articles.abstract: The massacre at a church in Charleston, S.C., this month casts the tensions between the Old South and the New into sharp relief.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — In a rambling home at the edge of a salt marsh, a proud graduate of the Citadel, the storied Southern military college whose cadets fired the opening salvo of the Civil War, was deep in prayer with a Bible study group.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: As Left Wins Culture Battles, G.O.P. Gains Opportunity to Pivot for 2016
articles.snippet: Many party officials see an opening to turn the election toward economic and national security issues.
articles.abstract: Many party officials see an opening to turn the election toward economic and national security issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A cascade of events suggests that 2015 could be remembered as a Liberal Spring: the moment when deeply divisive and consuming questions of race, sexuality and broadened access to health care were settled in quick succession, and social tolerance was cemented as a cornerstone of American public life.

articles.headline: Trying to Placate All, Iran Leader Zigs and Zags on Nuclear Talks
articles.snippet: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei’s ambiguity, meant to keep the moderate opposition happy while placating the hard-liners, has been part of his strategy for more than a decade.
articles.abstract: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei’s ambiguity, meant to keep the moderate opposition happy while placating the hard-liners, has been part of his strategy for more than a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Persian carpets were rolled out in the Beit-e Rahbar, the downtown Tehran offices of Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, on Tuesday, a sign that important guests were on their way.

articles.headline: Panic Sets in Among Hardy Hedge Fund Investors Remaining in Greece
articles.snippet: The question of what happens when the markets open on Monday is particularly acute for the hedge funds that held onto their Greek investments.
articles.abstract: The question of what happens when the markets open on Monday is particularly acute for the hedge funds that held onto their Greek investments.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — For investors around the world looking at Greece, there was but one question Sunday: What is going to happen when the markets open?

articles.headline: 5 Days That Left a Confederate Flag Wavering, and Likely to Fall
articles.snippet: Through churches, social media and the relatives of the nine African-Americans who were killed in Charleston, S.C., a campaign converted or tamed opponents.
articles.abstract: Through churches, social media and the relatives of the nine African-Americans who were killed in Charleston, S.C., a campaign converted or tamed opponents.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inside the old granite State House in South Carolina, one day after the massacre in a Charleston church, an African-American receptionist politely gave everyone who called to complain about the Confederate battle flag the same response: “Sorry, there’s nothing to be done.”
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Puerto Rico’s Governor Says Island’s Debts Are ‘Not Payable’
articles.snippet: Gov. Alejandro García Padilla said that his administration would probably seek significant concessions from its creditors on a $72 billion debt load.
articles.abstract: Gov. Alejandro García Padilla said that his administration would probably seek significant concessions from its creditors on a $72 billion debt load.
articles.lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico’s governor, saying he needs to pull the island out of a “death spiral,” has concluded that the commonwealth cannot pay its roughly $72 billion in debts, an admission that will probably have wide-reaching financial repercussions.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: When a Company Is Put Up for Sale, in Many Cases, Your Personal Data Is, Too
articles.snippet: Some consumer websites say they will not sell users’ data, but unrestricted-data clauses allow them to transfer it if a merger or other transaction occurs.
articles.abstract: Some consumer websites say they will not sell users’ data, but unrestricted-data clauses allow them to transfer it if a merger or other transaction occurs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The privacy policy for Hulu, a video-streaming service with about nine million subscribers, opens with a declaration that the company “respects your privacy.”
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and Jeremy B. Merrill

articles.headline: With Same-Sex Decision, Evangelical Churches Address New Reality
articles.snippet: The dramatic shift in public opinion, and now in the nation’s laws, on same-sex marriage has left evangelical Protestants in an uncomfortable position.
articles.abstract: The dramatic shift in public opinion, and now in the nation’s laws, on same-sex marriage has left evangelical Protestants in an uncomfortable position.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST CHICAGO, Ill. — The tone of the worship service was set at the start. An opening prayer declared it “a dark day.” The sermon focused on a psalm of lament. In between, a pastor read a statement proclaiming the church’s elders and staff “deeply saddened.”

articles.headline: Greece Will Shut Banks in Fallout From Debt Crisis
articles.snippet: The prime minister’s decisions escalated tensions and uncertainty over a financial crisis that some analysts say could have global ripples.
articles.abstract: The prime minister’s decisions escalated tensions and uncertainty over a financial crisis that some analysts say could have global ripples.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras announced Sunday night that Greece’s banks would be closed as of Monday, as the fallout from ruptured debt negotiations with the nation’s creditors began inflicting pain on ordinary people while raising alarm in Washington, Brussels and Berlin.

articles.headline: Comic-Con, Defending Fantasy Culture and, Now, Its Brand
articles.snippet: Many years on, a San Diego mainstay faces a new lineup of villains and peril.
articles.abstract: Many years on, a San Diego mainstay faces a new lineup of villains and peril.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — From the superheroic Avengers to the steampunk League of Extraordinary Gentlemen, the comics world is full of murky alliances.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Agency Taps Mapping Technology to Curb Rail Crossing Accidents
articles.snippet: The Federal Railroad Administration is hoping its new measure to integrate grade-crossing locations into mapping technology will curb the recent increase in crashes and fatalities.
articles.abstract: The Federal Railroad Administration is hoping its new measure to integrate grade-crossing locations into mapping technology will curb the recent increase in crashes and fatalities.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a sharp increase in the number of rail crossing accidents last year, the Federal Railroad Administration plans to announce a new partnership with Google on Monday to provide the locations of all grade crossings in the company’s popular map application.

articles.headline: State Marijuana Laws Complicate Federal Job Recruitment
articles.snippet: Applicants living where marijuana is legal are being warned that federal agencies still will not tolerate its use.
articles.abstract: Applicants living where marijuana is legal are being warned that federal agencies still will not tolerate its use.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For all the aspiring and current spies, diplomats and F.B.I. agents living in states that have liberalized marijuana laws, the federal government has a stern warning: Put down the bong, throw out the vaporizer and lose the rolling papers.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Supreme Court Allows Use of Execution Drug
articles.snippet: The justices sided against three inmates who had sought to bar a sedative. In the process, two dissenting members of the court came very close to calling the death penalty itself unconstitutional.
articles.abstract: The justices sided against three inmates who had sought to bar a sedative. In the process, two dissenting members of the court came very close to calling the death penalty itself unconstitutional.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court  ruled on Monday against three death row inmates who had sought to bar the use of an execution drug they said risked causing excruciating pain.

articles.headline: Supreme Court to Weigh Race in College Admissions
articles.snippet: The court has agreed to take another look at a challenge to the use of race in admissions decisions by the University of Texas at Austin, reviving a challenge to affirmative action in higher education.
articles.abstract: The court has agreed to take another look at a challenge to the use of race in admissions decisions by the University of Texas at Austin, reviving a challenge to affirmative action in higher education.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to take a second look at the use of race in admissions decisions by the University of Texas at Austin, reviving a potent challenge to affirmative action in higher education.
